statement.para: Determine if the equations below are equivalent.

answer.para: We notice that multiplying the first equation by 2 yields the second equation. So each solution of one of these equations is also a solution of the other. Therefore their solution sets form the same hyperplane in \RNr[3]: the hyperplane perpendicular to \Vect{n}:=(2,3,-1) passing through (0,0,-1).

statement.para: Determine if the equations below are equivalent.

answer.para: We notice that multiplying the left hand side of the first equation by 3 yields the left hand side of the second equation. However, multiplying the right hand side of the first equation by 3 yields 3\neq 5. Therefore it is not the case that one equation is a nonzero multiple of the other: the equations are not equivalent.
